author: sproul
content:
`newPayload` only accepts a single payload

the `params` are a list because JSON-RPC always uses a list for params

see the spec: <https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/blob/main/src/engine/paris.md#engine_newpayloadv1>

author: sproul
content: it's similar for new_PayloadV2/V3 as well

author: foflexity
content: Damn, I really should have realized that, I’m plenty familiar with JSON-RPC

author: foflexity
content: I switched to sending a batch of JSON-RPC payloads shortly after asking here, which works almost as well as if newPayload did actually accept an array of payloads (just some more overhead I suppose)

author: foflexity
content: Are there any other strategies I may be missing to accomplish an initial load like this?  I have a network with many blocks, I am pushing them into an execution client, but the blocks in question haven’t ever been validated or loaded into a traditional Ethereum client at all so there are no peers from which to request them (our runtime/RPC are entirely bespoke currently, we are integrating a traditional client to use as RPC for ease of operation and better compatibility)

author: sproul
content: none that I'm aware of, spamming them in one at a time with `newPayload` is probably your best bet
